HOPKINS SOLDIERS REVIEWED
Capt. Kirk, U.S. A., Visits Local Student
Battalion and Commends Work.
Orders for New Equipment Sent In.

Every step taken towards the installation of military training at
Hopkins has led to the success of
the movement. On last Wednesday the battalion was inspected by
Dean Brush, Captain Kirk of the
War Department and members of
the faculty, who were all deeply
impressed with the enthusiastic yet
serious manner in which the members of the battalion conducted
themselves, and with their ability
to carry out properly the commands
of Mr. Kistler and the leaders.
After watching the company drill
for a short time, Captain Kirk was
introduced by Dr. Abercrombie,
and spoke to the corps as they stood
at rest. He said that as it was
customary for the War Department to send men to various colleges to see if they had the proper
number of men and facilities, he
had been sent to Hopkins to see
how matters stood. Not only did
he find facilities, but also that which
is more necessary, an enthusiastic
capable corps of students whom he
felt sure would make a success of
this movement. Consequently he
felt no doubt of the fast that an
officer would soon be sent over to
take the battalion in charge, since
the bill providing for military
training of this kind has already
passed the House, and will probably
meet with little opposition in the
Senate.
In the meantime, the Dean has
put in a request for 130 rifles,
which will probably arrive at an
early date; and although new uniforms cannot be furnished at present, old ones may be sent from
Washington for the use of the
members of the corps. It has been
suggested that in order to secure
unity of costume for the sake of
appearance, the students taking the
'training wear white duck trousers
and white shirts during the drills
at . Homewood, which began last
Friday.
On last Monday Mr. Kistler had
four of the leaders drill the company and this plan proved very
successful. As it is Mr. Kistler's
wish to put the responsibility of the
drilling as much as possible upon
the men themselves, he will continue in this course, giving the different leaders opportunity to drill
the company in order to give the
corps members a chance to decide
whom they want for 'officers when
the battalion is organized. On
'Wednesday and Friday more of the

BRENNICK FOOTBALL COACH

On Monday, April 3, 1916, at a
meeting of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Board, at the recommendation
of the football committee, Mr.
Henry Brennick was appointed
football coach for the coming year.
Mr. Brennick is a Harvard graduate and is well known as a football coach. For a time he was assistant coach at Harvard, and the
records of the teams which he has
developed at different preparatory
schools in Baltimore and elsewhere,
in themselves bear sufficient testimony to his ability in this line of
football work.
Although there were many AllAmerican men available, and although several prominent alumni
applied for the position, the committee quickly decided upon Mr.
Brennick. Considering the knowledge and ability Mr. Brennick has
shown in football matters, their
choice is not to be questioned. Furthermore, Mr. Brennick knows
more about football conditions at
Hopkins than does any other man,
with the exception of Charles
Brickley, and his services as assistant coach last year under the latter
will enable him easily to step into
the vacated position.
BILLY SUNDAY TO SPEAK TO
STUDENTS FRIDAY, APRIL 14

It has been announced that Billy
Sunday will speak at Johns Hopkins University on Friday, April 14,
at 12 o'clock noon.
Rumors concerning the appearance of Mr. Sunday at McCoy Hall
have been spread thoroughout his
campaign in Baltimore, and repeated
efforts have been made to secure
him—none succeeding until now.
A large attendance is expected.
ONLY FEW MORE DAYS TO
CONTRIBUTE TO MEMORIAL

April 15 will be the last day on
which contributions to the Layfield
Memorial Fund will be received.
The committee in charge of the
fund reports that the donations so
far have been exceedingly generous,
but it is still desirous that every
possible contribution be forthcoming, in order that the memorial may
be a worthy one.
All donations should be given to
Theodore Straus, Hiram Woodward, '16, or Franklin Sutton, '18.

The annual appropriation of the
State to Johns Hopkins University
has been cut from $25,000 to $15,000.
Immediately before its adjournment, the Maryland Legislature
passed a bill which provided for the
support of all the institutions wholly or in part dependent upon the
State, and it was in this bill that
the reduction in the 'Hopkins grant
was brought about. Indeed, as
first introduced, the bill provided
none of the original grant, and it
was only upon amendment that the
University received any appropriation whatsoever.
The $50,000 grant to the Engineering School granted by the
Legislature is entirely separate
from the $15,000 which is given to
the University in general. The former grant is made compulsory by
the act of a former Legislature,
and its renewal is almost automatic.
The granting of this fund, however, naturally precludes all talk
of the withdrawal of the Maryland
scholarships given by the Engineering School, as these are in no way
affected by the cut in the general
appropriation.
The action of the Legislature in
reducing the grant comes as a disappointment to the University, but
hardly as a surprise. Since the
opening of the session, a cut in the
Hopkins appropriation had been
constantly mentioned as one of the
easiest methods of reducing the
State's expenditures, and at first it
was feared that the entire grant
would be withdrawn. It was due to
the appeals of President Goodnow
and of the Board of Trustees, as
well as to the determined fight put
up within the Legislature itself by
such men as Ex-Speaker Trippe
and Senator Archer that the $15,000 itself was obtained. rt is understood that the definite stand taken by the Go'vernor in favor of at
least a partial grant finally influenced the action of the Legislature.
While the withdrawal of the
$io,000 , will be a serious loss to
Hopkins, it will not interfere with
the removal of the University to
Homewood next fall. Indeed, it is
estimated that money would be lost
by further delay due to the expense
of keeping the new buildings idle,
and to the sum which can be realized from the present buildings,
once that they are vacated.

Dr. Harry Clary Jones, professor
of physical chemistry ill this University, died suddenly on Sunday,
April 9, 1916, the exact cause of
his death not being known. Dr.
Jones had been ill for about two
months, but had continued his work
at the University until ten days before his death, when he was practically forced to remain at his home
by friends who saw that he was
rapidly becoming more and more
nervous.
Following his death, the body was
sent to the Johns Hopkins Hospital,
where Dr. Wintcrnitz made an investigation into the cause of his
death. Results of the autopsy have
not as yet been announced.
Dr. Jones was an incessant worker. He was in the habit of spending every minute possible in the laboratory, and in the course of the
twenty-two years that he was a
member of the University faculty,
he made countless investigations,
publishing several books and hundreds of papers, many of which give
details of discoveries most important to the advancement of his science. The original work done by
him and under his direction probably amounts to more than that any
other chemist in this country has
produced in the same time. At the
time of his death he was engaged
in research which promised to throw
new light on several subjects of
importance.
In spite of the fact that he was
constantly using up more nervous
energy than that accredited to most
men of his age, he would never take
a vacation. Friends and co-workers
on the faculty made repeated attempts to induce him to go to the
seashore for a period of weeks, in
order to build up the nervous force
he was fast sapping by his constant
devotion to his work, but he insisted
that it was absolutely necessary for
him to continue his daily appearance at the laboratory, and it was
only when he became so exceedingly nervous that danger seemed iminent that he consented to remain at
his home. During the summer, he
would remain in Baltimore, going
daily to the University, where he
worked steadily on whatever problems he had in hand.
Dr. Jones graduated from this
University as a bachelor of arts in
1889. and continued his studies here
until the attainment of his doctor's
degree, which he received in 1892.
He then took up the study of physical chemistry at Leipzig, Stockholm

Graduate Students of University Meet
to Form Socialist Society—Members Not Believers in
Socialism.

A club for the stud of Socialism
was formed following a luncheon
at the Emerson on Saturday, April
1, by graduate students in several
departments of the University. Dr.
Harry W. Laidler, secretary of the
Intercollegiate Socialist Society,
who has been making a tour of the
southern. colleges and universities,
stopped in Baltimore on his way .
back to New York, was present at
the luncheon and gave a talk on the
general history and development of
Socialism, and of the organization
of Socialist clubs in the various
universities of the country. He
sketched the purposes, aims and
methods of procedure in vogue in
the other college Socialist clubs,
and gave some advice as to how the
newly inaugurated club at Hopkins
might best proceed in the study of
Social:sm. Dr. Laidler had been in
Belgium in the summer of 1914,
and he gave a vivid description of
the Socialist meetings there on July
29 of that year, the eve of the great
European war.
The students who have entered
this club are not professed Socialists. Some are heartily against
it. They have come together merely to study a subject that is not
included in the regular university
courses.
Those present at the organization of the club were: W.B. Schulz,
A. Thalheimer, Dr. Leo Wolman,
H. M. Blalock, 1-1. C. Evans, Herbert Onsley, F. L. Mohler, W. K.
Woolery, E. M. Carr, H. F.
Holtzclaw, Jesse S. Robinson,
*James T. Carter, Edgar T. Fell
and Bruce Williams. Broadus
Mitchell, who acted as toastmaster
at the luncheon, was elected permanent chairman of the newly organized club.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 10, 1916.
PLANS FOR DEBATE COMPLETE

FRESH1ES BANQUET AT RENNERT

Triangular Contest Judges Selected and
Committees in Charge Appointed.
Small "H" for Watch Fob
Suggested as Emblem.

- Class of 1919 Holds First Annual"Feed"
Last Wednesday Many Speeches
and Toasts Show Spirit of
First-Year Men.

At a meeting of the Debating
Council held last Friday afternoon,
judges for the coming triangular
eontest with the universities of
North Carolina and Virginia were
selected; a manager for the Hopkins teams and several important
committees were appointed, and it
was definitely decided that the offer
of the Tau Kappa Alpha Debating
Fraternity to establish a chapter
here would have to be rejected.
The meeting, called to order by
President Coffin, first considered
the lists of judges which the two
Southern uninversities had submitted to the secretary for the debates
to take place at Chapel Hill and
Charlottesville. These lists were
found to be entirely satisfactory,
and the Council then proceeded to
draw up a list of its own for the
debate between North Carolina and
Virginia, which is to take place at
this University.
Alexander A. Steinbach, the secretary-treasurer of the Council,
was made the manager of the Hopkins teams. An entertainment committee, consisting of Gichner, Steinbach and Oppenheimer, was next
appointed by the president to provide for the reception of the visiting teams, and to make arrangements for their accommodation
during their stay in Baltimore. To
insure interest in the debate, a publicity committee, consisting of Gichner and Oppenheimer, was appointed, and was instructed, as part of
its work, to mail announcements of
the debate to such alumni of North
Carolina and Virginia as were in
the city.
The Council then proceeded to
consider the offer of the Tau Kappa
Alpha, which was received about a
month ago. After some discussion,
it was decided that the number of
men on the Hopkins teams who remained in the University for any
length of time was too small to
allow an active chapter to be founded, and that the official blue "H"
given by the University to all 'Varsity debaters was in itself sufficient
honor.
A- plan, which was advanced at
the meeting and which was received favorably by the Council,
proposed to allim. each man upon
whom such an .1 I" was bestowed
to wear a snmll gold "II" either
upon his watch-guard or his fob.
These "Hs" are awarded for debating- at many of the larger
'
: 1101)leg-es, and are highly prized
would, of course, be enkins
tirely distinct from any athletic insignia, as the Gothic points of the
blue "II" would be preserved.
The University of Missouri now
has a lunch room which can serve
about soo students. The average
cost of a meal is only about thirteen
cents.—Ex.

The banquet of the Class of 1919,
which was held ,Wednesday, April
5, 1916, at the Rennert Hotel, was
an undeniable success from the
time when Harris E. Kirk, Jr., the
toastmaster, gave the opening
speech to the last "I Iullabaloo" with
a "Hopkins on the end."
After the coffee, the toastmaster announced the first speaker of
the evening, Ronald Cox, whose
subject was "The Class." Cox
gave a general review of what the
Class of '19 has accomplished in
the way of scholastic and athletic
endeavors. He pointed to the college spirit which the freshmen have
helped to arouse in the University,
and in closing made a plea for a
still better organization for the following year.
Next, Raymond E. Lenhard
spoke on the somewhat ambiguous
topic "Why and Wherefore." After confessing that he was quite at
a loss as to what subject his topic
rightly belonged, Lenhard gave a
brief review of the vhvs and
wherefores of class activities.
After this, Adolph L. Hamburger (rave a well delivered and serious talk on "The Future." He
pointed out all the opportunities
that lie before the class. Amid
much applause he prophesied that
the Class of '19 would have one of
the most successful careers of any
class that has ever entered Hopkins.
The last speech, and one of the
best, was that made by Warren
Allen on "Calisthenics." After
enumerating all the sports in
which freshmen had displayed an
interest, he commented on the victories that the Class of '19 had
won. Besides showing how freshmen had starred in football, lacrosse, track and other sports, he
made mention of the activities of
the basket-ball league and of the
wrestling club, in which 1919 has
played so prominent a part.
Next came a toast "To His
Namesake," by Richard Cox. Then
Roszel C. Thomsen gave a serious
talk on "Morals and Traditions."
He lay special emphasis on the traditions that Hopkins has upheld
and urged that the Class of '19
live up to them as previous classes
have done.
This was followed by a fitting tribute to the sophomores, by C. Herbert Baxley. With a few wellchosen remarks he gave a toast to
the Class of '18, wishing them the
best of luck 'and a successful future. After the applause had died.
down, Mitchell B. Carroll gave a
toast "To the Class." Immediately
after this three Hullabaloos were
given, one for the sophomores,
another for the Class of '19, and
a third for Johns Hopkins.
During the intervals between
speeches music was supplied by

Young's Orchestra, which played
all the Hopkins songs.
The hanquet committee was composed of H. 1. Kirk, Jr., chairman; Mitchell B. Carroll, Crawford R. Haskell, Charles 1-1. Baxley, William H. Stokes and Christian A. Lentz.

Seniors to Banquet at City Club.

The 1916 Senior Class banquet
is to be held this Monday night at
the City Club at 8 o'clock, and a
great success is looked forward to
as the committee, which is composed of McDowell, chairman;
Vickers, Bagley and Ludington,
has made very elaborate plans. It
is expected that Dr. Goodnow, the
president of the University, will be
the guest of honor and will deliver
an address on some pertinent subject. Also Dr. Latane, the honorary president of the Senior Class,
is to be present and will speak. The
third speaker will probably be Manuel Gichner.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 10, 1916.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes great
pleasure in announcing the election
to its Editorial Board of Richard H.
Woodward, 'i8; Franklin M. Earnest, '19; Mitchell B. Carroll, 'i9;
and Roszel C. Thomsen, '19. At
the same time, it regrets to announce the resignation of Hiram
W. Woodward, '16.
The Layfield Memorial Fund.

This Saturday will bring with it
the last opportunity present Hopkins students will ever have for
showing their appreciation of a man
who was, in the noblest sense of the
word, a hero. To that man we are
about to erect a memorial—a memorial which will stand as a tribute
and as an inspiration for all future
generations. Let the final completion of the fund from which the memorial is to be erected mean that
every man for whom it was possible
has taken part in its upbuilding. In
the few days left, let it be made, as
it should be made, a memorial dedicated by all Hopkins.

MUSICAL CLUBS EXTEND SEASON
Four Additional Concerts Arranged for
Dates in April and May, With
More Pending—Success
Now Sure.

The season of the Musical Clubs
has been extended this year somewhat more than usual, owing to the
occurrence of good opportunities for
concerts at late dates. The clubs
will appear on Ap*ril ir at the Baltimore City College; on April 28, at
Strawbridge M. E. Church, on May
2, in Washington, D. C.; and on
May 5 and May 9 at local church
concerts. Engagements for the
Easter vacation have not as yet been
announced, but it is understood that
attempts are being made to secure
an out-of-town appearance.
The Washington concert promises
to be one of the biggest out-of-town
engagements filled by the combined
clubs. It will be given for the benefit of the Episcopal Eye, Ear and
Throat Hospital of that city, and
will attract a large and fashionable
audience. Effort will be made to
secure the patronage of the President and Secretary Baker, both of
whom, as alumni of Johns Hopkins,
are interested in the work of the
clubs. President Wilson was himself a member of the Glee Club during his residence here as a student.
The concert will be given in the
ballroom of the Hotel Raleigh on
May 2.
In view of the additions to the
schedule, both glee and mandolin
clubs will do extra work to make
their last concerts the best. The
Glee Club will make additions to
its repertory, and the Mandolin
Club will aim to perfect the music
now ill hand.'
These last concerts will mark the
close of one of the most successful
years the clubs have had. Musically, their work has gained them a
very good reputation, both glee and
mandolin clubs becoming popular
at every concert. Their program
has been varied and full of life, presenting something of practically
every type of music available and
carefully made selections at that.
Much work and care has been put
on this side of the activity, and results have shown all effort to have
been worth while.
Financially, the clubs are in a
healthy condition. Careful and
prudent management has brought
the condition of the treasury far
above normal, ensuring safety from
possible failure. Every phase of
the musicians' endeavor is in good
condition for the .building up of
clubs ranking among the best. Continuance of good management, together with a normal supply of good
material from incoming classes and
-consistent support by those who are
able, is all that is needed.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 10, 1916.

6
SOPHOMORES KEEP RANKS SOLID
Hold Banquet at Rennert on Night of
April 4 Efforts of Freshmen to
Outwit Them Fail Speeches
All Well Received.

• The Sophomore Class successfully held their banquet on April
4, in spite of the efforts of the
freshmen to abduct their principal
speakers. Although the freshmen
did all in their power to repay the
sophomores for their action in kidnapping .three of their men the
night before,on which date the firstyear men had for a time considered
having their banquet, the sophomores were able to keep their ranks
intact—every man who had previously notified the chairman of the
committee being present at the banquet.
There were many brisk encounters and many captures and "Deadeye Dick" escapes during the day
and a half preceding the banquet,
but the 1918 strategists were able
to outwit the freshmen and hold a
most enjoyable banquet.
The banquet itself was a highly
successful affair. The food was excellent and the speakers were well
chosen.
Alexander MON. Wolfe, the
president of the class, was toastmaster. Franklin Sutton, the first
speaker, gave a talk on the Memorial to Layfield, who was a member of the 1918 Class. Robert Duncan spoke on "Hazing-. and then
came Alec Randall, who had for his
subject "1918 at Homewood."
Then followed the two hits of
the, evening. Everett Sanner gave
"Casey at the Bat" in realistic form,
acting everything as he said it:
Reuben Oppenheimer then recited
two original poems, parodies on
"Danny Deever" and "Gonga Din."
Toastmaster Wolfe here called on
about a dozen of the members of
the class to tell of their experiences
during the fresh-soph struggle of.
that day or to tell of some college
activity in which they were espeThe banquet
cially interested.
closed with cheers for the class, its
members, and for the team.
The banquet committee consisted
of Henry Evans, chairman; Stuart
Egerton, Frank Sutton, Robert
Duncan and Robert Hoffman.
PRINCETON STATISTICS FURNISH
INTERESTING INFORMATION

The publication of the Princeton senior statistics has aroused
great discussion in college circles
throughout the country, both because of the actual information
conveyed, and because of the unusual nature of the canvass.
These statistics show that out of
230 men I9 are supporting themse:ves wholly and 38 partially.
Seven men have been suspended
from college. The average age of
the class is 21.7 years, one man
being only 18 years old.
Of the class 43 men declare that
they have . never kissed a girl.

CARROLL MANSION FOR CLUB

BALDWIN ASKS REPARATION

DO YOUR PRIMPING AT

Hopkins Club to Occupy Old Building
at Homewood Next Fall -Heating
and Lighting to Be
Altered.

Former Hopkins Professor Sends Stirring Cable to President, on Behalf
of His Injured Daughter Latter's Condition Critical.

The Citizens' Barber Shop

It has been definitely decided that
the Hopkins Club will occupy the
old Carroll Mansion when the University moves to Homewood next
fall. As the building is in need of
repairs, a committee consisting of
Messrs. Cator, Keyser and Radcliffe has been appointed to make
improvements. The committee, in
whose hands the entire matter has
been left, has had several architects
to look over the state of affairs and
to give estimates of the cost of the
needed renovations. As funds are
not plentiful, the treasurer has objected to a large appropriation.
However, $2,000 have been set
aside thus far.
The mansion must be altered
somewhat to suit the tastes and
needs of the club and yet its style
and colonial archecticture, both inside and out, must be kept intact.
No changes which will spoil the
design or alter in any way the appearance will be made. Of course,
this does not include papering and
painting; it is for these that the
estimates are being gathered.
Since gas is at present the only
means of illumination, an appropriation has been made to install
electric fixtures. Concerning the
heating apparatus no definite plans
have been decided upon. If the
heat could be secured from the
main supply-house of the University, it could be gotten more cheaply by the club and would aid the
University. This idea would necessitate the tearing up of the lawn
and campus to lay down the big
pipes. The house is now heated by
three large, but old fashioned furnaces, the upkeep of which is enormous compared with the cost of
heat from the main pipes.

Dr. James Mark Baldwin, a former Hopkins professor, who is a
survivor of the channel-ship Sussex
which sank recently as the result of
an explosion supposed to have been
caused by a German submarine attack, sent a cablegram last week to
President Wilson asking reparation
for the injuries received by his
daughter.
The cablegram read as follows:
"A woman traveling where her
right was, carrying an American
passport, stricken on the Sussex,
hovering between life and death,
demands that reparation for assault on American life and liberty
be exacted. MARK BALDWIN."
Miss Baldwin's injuries included
paralysis of the right side and she
was unable to speak from the time
of the accident until April 1, when
she recovered her voice. Her condition is still alarming serious and
it is supposed that Dr. Baldwin will
remain in Paris with his daughter
for some time to come.

HOPKINS SOLDIERS REVIEWED
Capt. Kirk, U.S. A., Visits Local Student
Battalion and Commends Work.
Orders for New Equipment Sent In.

Every step taken towards the installation of military training at
Hopkins has led to the success of
the movement. On last Wednesday the battalion was inspected by
Dean Brush, Captain Kirk of the
War Department and members of
the faculty, who were all deeply
impressed with the enthusiastic yet
serious manner in which the members of the battalion conducted
themselves, and with their ability
to carry out properly the commands
of Mr. Kistler and the leaders.
After watching the company drill
for a short time, Captain Kirk was
introduced by Dr. Abercrombie,
and spoke to the corps as they stood
at rest. He said that as it was
customary for the War Department to send men to various colleges to see if they had the proper
number of men and facilities, he
had been sent to Hopkins to see
how matters stood. Not only did
he find facilities, but also that which
is more necessary, an enthusiastic
capable corps of students whom he
felt sure would make a success of
this movement. Consequently he
felt no doubt of the fast that an
officer would soon be sent over to
take the battalion in charge, since
the bill providing for military
training of this kind has already
passed the House, and will probably
meet with little opposition in the
Senate.
In the meantime, the Dean has
put in a request for 130 rifles,
which will probably arrive at an
early date; and although new uniforms cannot be furnished at present, old ones may be sent from
Washington for the use of the
members of the corps. It has been
suggested that in order to secure
unity of costume for the sake of
appearance, the students taking the
'training wear white duck trousers
and white shirts during the drills
at . Homewood, which began last
Friday.
On last Monday Mr. Kistler had
four of the leaders drill the company and this plan proved very
successful. As it is Mr. Kistler's
wish to put the responsibility of the
drilling as much as possible upon
the men themselves, he will continue in this course, giving the different leaders opportunity to drill
the company in order to give the
corps members a chance to decide
whom they want for 'officers when
the battalion is organized. On
'Wednesday and Friday more of the

BRENNICK FOOTBALL COACH

On Monday, April 3, 1916, at a
meeting of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Board, at the recommendation
of the football committee, Mr.
Henry Brennick was appointed
football coach for the coming year.
Mr. Brennick is a Harvard graduate and is well known as a football coach. For a time he was assistant coach at Harvard, and the
records of the teams which he has
developed at different preparatory
schools in Baltimore and elsewhere,
in themselves bear sufficient testimony to his ability in this line of
football work.
Although there were many AllAmerican men available, and although several prominent alumni
applied for the position, the committee quickly decided upon Mr.
Brennick. Considering the knowledge and ability Mr. Brennick has
shown in football matters, their
choice is not to be questioned. Furthermore, Mr. Brennick knows
more about football conditions at
Hopkins than does any other man,
with the exception of Charles
Brickley, and his services as assistant coach last year under the latter
will enable him easily to step into
the vacated position.
BILLY SUNDAY TO SPEAK TO
STUDENTS FRIDAY, APRIL 14

It has been announced that Billy
Sunday will speak at Johns Hopkins University on Friday, April 14,
at 12 o'clock noon.
Rumors concerning the appearance of Mr. Sunday at McCoy Hall
have been spread thoroughout his
campaign in Baltimore, and repeated
efforts have been made to secure
him—none succeeding until now.
A large attendance is expected.
ONLY FEW MORE DAYS TO
CONTRIBUTE TO MEMORIAL

April 15 will be the last day on
which contributions to the Layfield
Memorial Fund will be received.
The committee in charge of the
fund reports that the donations so
far have been exceedingly generous,
but it is still desirous that every
possible contribution be forthcoming, in order that the memorial may
be a worthy one.
All donations should be given to
Theodore Straus, Hiram Woodward, '16, or Franklin Sutton, '18.

The annual appropriation of the
State to Johns Hopkins University
has been cut from $25,000 to $15,000.
Immediately before its adjournment, the Maryland Legislature
passed a bill which provided for the
support of all the institutions wholly or in part dependent upon the
State, and it was in this bill that
the reduction in the 'Hopkins grant
was brought about. Indeed, as
first introduced, the bill provided
none of the original grant, and it
was only upon amendment that the
University received any appropriation whatsoever.
The $50,000 grant to the Engineering School granted by the
Legislature is entirely separate
from the $15,000 which is given to
the University in general. The former grant is made compulsory by
the act of a former Legislature,
and its renewal is almost automatic.
The granting of this fund, however, naturally precludes all talk
of the withdrawal of the Maryland
scholarships given by the Engineering School, as these are in no way
affected by the cut in the general
appropriation.
The action of the Legislature in
reducing the grant comes as a disappointment to the University, but
hardly as a surprise. Since the
opening of the session, a cut in the
Hopkins appropriation had been
constantly mentioned as one of the
easiest methods of reducing the
State's expenditures, and at first it
was feared that the entire grant
would be withdrawn. It was due to
the appeals of President Goodnow
and of the Board of Trustees, as
well as to the determined fight put
up within the Legislature itself by
such men as Ex-Speaker Trippe
and Senator Archer that the $15,000 itself was obtained. rt is understood that the definite stand taken by the Go'vernor in favor of at
least a partial grant finally influenced the action of the Legislature.
While the withdrawal of the
$io,000 , will be a serious loss to
Hopkins, it will not interfere with
the removal of the University to
Homewood next fall. Indeed, it is
estimated that money would be lost
by further delay due to the expense
of keeping the new buildings idle,
and to the sum which can be realized from the present buildings,
once that they are vacated.

Dr. Harry Clary Jones, professor
of physical chemistry ill this University, died suddenly on Sunday,
April 9, 1916, the exact cause of
his death not being known. Dr.
Jones had been ill for about two
months, but had continued his work
at the University until ten days before his death, when he was practically forced to remain at his home
by friends who saw that he was
rapidly becoming more and more
nervous.
Following his death, the body was
sent to the Johns Hopkins Hospital,
where Dr. Wintcrnitz made an investigation into the cause of his
death. Results of the autopsy have
not as yet been announced.
Dr. Jones was an incessant worker. He was in the habit of spending every minute possible in the laboratory, and in the course of the
twenty-two years that he was a
member of the University faculty,
he made countless investigations,
publishing several books and hundreds of papers, many of which give
details of discoveries most important to the advancement of his science. The original work done by
him and under his direction probably amounts to more than that any
other chemist in this country has
produced in the same time. At the
time of his death he was engaged
in research which promised to throw
new light on several subjects of
importance.
In spite of the fact that he was
constantly using up more nervous
energy than that accredited to most
men of his age, he would never take
a vacation. Friends and co-workers
on the faculty made repeated attempts to induce him to go to the
seashore for a period of weeks, in
order to build up the nervous force
he was fast sapping by his constant
devotion to his work, but he insisted
that it was absolutely necessary for
him to continue his daily appearance at the laboratory, and it was
only when he became so exceedingly nervous that danger seemed iminent that he consented to remain at
his home. During the summer, he
would remain in Baltimore, going
daily to the University, where he
worked steadily on whatever problems he had in hand.
Dr. Jones graduated from this
University as a bachelor of arts in
1889. and continued his studies here
until the attainment of his doctor's
degree, which he received in 1892.
He then took up the study of physical chemistry at Leipzig, Stockholm

Graduate Students of University Meet
to Form Socialist Society—Members Not Believers in
Socialism.

A club for the stud of Socialism
was formed following a luncheon
at the Emerson on Saturday, April
1, by graduate students in several
departments of the University. Dr.
Harry W. Laidler, secretary of the
Intercollegiate Socialist Society,
who has been making a tour of the
southern. colleges and universities,
stopped in Baltimore on his way .
back to New York, was present at
the luncheon and gave a talk on the
general history and development of
Socialism, and of the organization
of Socialist clubs in the various
universities of the country. He
sketched the purposes, aims and
methods of procedure in vogue in
the other college Socialist clubs,
and gave some advice as to how the
newly inaugurated club at Hopkins
might best proceed in the study of
Social:sm. Dr. Laidler had been in
Belgium in the summer of 1914,
and he gave a vivid description of
the Socialist meetings there on July
29 of that year, the eve of the great
European war.
The students who have entered
this club are not professed Socialists. Some are heartily against
it. They have come together merely to study a subject that is not
included in the regular university
courses.
Those present at the organization of the club were: W.B. Schulz,
A. Thalheimer, Dr. Leo Wolman,
H. M. Blalock, 1-1. C. Evans, Herbert Onsley, F. L. Mohler, W. K.
Woolery, E. M. Carr, H. F.
Holtzclaw, Jesse S. Robinson,
*James T. Carter, Edgar T. Fell
and Bruce Williams. Broadus
Mitchell, who acted as toastmaster
at the luncheon, was elected permanent chairman of the newly organized club.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 10, 1916.
PLANS FOR DEBATE COMPLETE

FRESH1ES BANQUET AT RENNERT

Triangular Contest Judges Selected and
Committees in Charge Appointed.
Small "H" for Watch Fob
Suggested as Emblem.

- Class of 1919 Holds First Annual"Feed"
Last Wednesday Many Speeches
and Toasts Show Spirit of
First-Year Men.

At a meeting of the Debating
Council held last Friday afternoon,
judges for the coming triangular
eontest with the universities of
North Carolina and Virginia were
selected; a manager for the Hopkins teams and several important
committees were appointed, and it
was definitely decided that the offer
of the Tau Kappa Alpha Debating
Fraternity to establish a chapter
here would have to be rejected.
The meeting, called to order by
President Coffin, first considered
the lists of judges which the two
Southern uninversities had submitted to the secretary for the debates
to take place at Chapel Hill and
Charlottesville. These lists were
found to be entirely satisfactory,
and the Council then proceeded to
draw up a list of its own for the
debate between North Carolina and
Virginia, which is to take place at
this University.
Alexander A. Steinbach, the secretary-treasurer of the Council,
was made the manager of the Hopkins teams. An entertainment committee, consisting of Gichner, Steinbach and Oppenheimer, was next
appointed by the president to provide for the reception of the visiting teams, and to make arrangements for their accommodation
during their stay in Baltimore. To
insure interest in the debate, a publicity committee, consisting of Gichner and Oppenheimer, was appointed, and was instructed, as part of
its work, to mail announcements of
the debate to such alumni of North
Carolina and Virginia as were in
the city.
The Council then proceeded to
consider the offer of the Tau Kappa
Alpha, which was received about a
month ago. After some discussion,
it was decided that the number of
men on the Hopkins teams who remained in the University for any
length of time was too small to
allow an active chapter to be founded, and that the official blue "H"
given by the University to all 'Varsity debaters was in itself sufficient
honor.
A- plan, which was advanced at
the meeting and which was received favorably by the Council,
proposed to allim. each man upon
whom such an .1 I" was bestowed
to wear a snmll gold "II" either
upon his watch-guard or his fob.
These "Hs" are awarded for debating- at many of the larger
'
: 1101)leg-es, and are highly prized
would, of course, be enkins
tirely distinct from any athletic insignia, as the Gothic points of the
blue "II" would be preserved.
The University of Missouri now
has a lunch room which can serve
about soo students. The average
cost of a meal is only about thirteen
cents.—Ex.

The banquet of the Class of 1919,
which was held ,Wednesday, April
5, 1916, at the Rennert Hotel, was
an undeniable success from the
time when Harris E. Kirk, Jr., the
toastmaster, gave the opening
speech to the last "I Iullabaloo" with
a "Hopkins on the end."
After the coffee, the toastmaster announced the first speaker of
the evening, Ronald Cox, whose
subject was "The Class." Cox
gave a general review of what the
Class of '19 has accomplished in
the way of scholastic and athletic
endeavors. He pointed to the college spirit which the freshmen have
helped to arouse in the University,
and in closing made a plea for a
still better organization for the following year.
Next, Raymond E. Lenhard
spoke on the somewhat ambiguous
topic "Why and Wherefore." After confessing that he was quite at
a loss as to what subject his topic
rightly belonged, Lenhard gave a
brief review of the vhvs and
wherefores of class activities.
After this, Adolph L. Hamburger (rave a well delivered and serious talk on "The Future." He
pointed out all the opportunities
that lie before the class. Amid
much applause he prophesied that
the Class of '19 would have one of
the most successful careers of any
class that has ever entered Hopkins.
The last speech, and one of the
best, was that made by Warren
Allen on "Calisthenics." After
enumerating all the sports in
which freshmen had displayed an
interest, he commented on the victories that the Class of '19 had
won. Besides showing how freshmen had starred in football, lacrosse, track and other sports, he
made mention of the activities of
the basket-ball league and of the
wrestling club, in which 1919 has
played so prominent a part.
Next came a toast "To His
Namesake," by Richard Cox. Then
Roszel C. Thomsen gave a serious
talk on "Morals and Traditions."
He lay special emphasis on the traditions that Hopkins has upheld
and urged that the Class of '19
live up to them as previous classes
have done.
This was followed by a fitting tribute to the sophomores, by C. Herbert Baxley. With a few wellchosen remarks he gave a toast to
the Class of '18, wishing them the
best of luck 'and a successful future. After the applause had died.
down, Mitchell B. Carroll gave a
toast "To the Class." Immediately
after this three Hullabaloos were
given, one for the sophomores,
another for the Class of '19, and
a third for Johns Hopkins.
During the intervals between
speeches music was supplied by

Young's Orchestra, which played
all the Hopkins songs.
The hanquet committee was composed of H. 1. Kirk, Jr., chairman; Mitchell B. Carroll, Crawford R. Haskell, Charles 1-1. Baxley, William H. Stokes and Christian A. Lentz.

This Saturday will bring with it
the last opportunity present Hopkins students will ever have for
showing their appreciation of a man
who was, in the noblest sense of the

generations. Let the final completion of the fund from which the memorial is to be erected mean that
every man for whom it was possible
has taken part in its upbuilding. In
the few days left, let it be made, as
it should be made, a memorial dedicated by all Hopkins.

MUSICAL CLUBS EXTEND SEASON
Four Additional Concerts Arranged for
Dates in April and May, With
More Pending—Success
Now Sure.

The season of the Musical Clubs
has been extended this year somewhat more than usual, owing to the
occurrence of good opportunities for
concerts at late dates. The clubs
will appear on Ap*ril ir at the Baltimore City College; on April 28, at
Strawbridge M. E. Church, on May
2, in Washington, D. C.; and on
May 5 and May 9 at local church
concerts. Engagements for the
Easter vacation have not as yet been
announced, but it is understood that
attempts are being made to secure
an out-of-town appearance.
The Washington concert promises
to be one of the biggest out-of-town
engagements filled by the combined
clubs. It will be given for the benefit of the Episcopal Eye, Ear and
Throat Hospital of that city, and
will attract a large and fashionable
audience. Effort will be made to
secure the patronage of the President and Secretary Baker, both of
whom, as alumni of Johns Hopkins,
are interested in the work of the
clubs. President Wilson was himself a member of the Glee Club during his residence here as a student.
The concert will be given in the
ballroom of the Hotel Raleigh on
May 2.
In view of the additions to the
schedule, both glee and mandolin
clubs will do extra work to make
their last concerts the best. The
Glee Club will make additions to
its repertory, and the Mandolin
Club will aim to perfect the music
now ill hand.'
These last concerts will mark the
close of one of the most successful
years the clubs have had. Musically, their work has gained them a
very good reputation, both glee and
mandolin clubs becoming popular
at every concert. Their program
has been varied and full of life, presenting something of practically
every type of music available and
carefully made selections at that.
Much work and care has been put
on this side of the activity, and results have shown all effort to have
been worth while.
Financially, the clubs are in a
healthy condition. Careful and
prudent management has brought
the condition of the treasury far
above normal, ensuring safety from
possible failure. Every phase of
the musicians' endeavor is in good
condition for the .building up of
clubs ranking among the best. Continuance of good management, together with a normal supply of good
material from incoming classes and
-consistent support by those who are
able, is all that is needed.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 10, 1916.

6
SOPHOMORES KEEP RANKS SOLID
Hold Banquet at Rennert on Night of
April 4 Efforts of Freshmen to
Outwit Them Fail Speeches
All Well Received.

• The Sophomore Class successfully held their banquet on April
4, in spite of the efforts of the
freshmen to abduct their principal
speakers. Although the freshmen
did all in their power to repay the
sophomores for their action in kidnapping .three of their men the
night before,on which date the firstyear men had for a time considered
having their banquet, the sophomores were able to keep their ranks
intact—every man who had previously notified the chairman of the
committee being present at the banquet.
There were many brisk encounters and many captures and "Deadeye Dick" escapes during the day
and a half preceding the banquet,
but the 1918 strategists were able
to outwit the freshmen and hold a
most enjoyable banquet.
The banquet itself was a highly
successful affair. The food was excellent and the speakers were well
chosen.
Alexander MON. Wolfe, the
president of the class, was toastmaster. Franklin Sutton, the first
speaker, gave a talk on the Memorial to Layfield, who was a member of the 1918 Class. Robert Duncan spoke on "Hazing-. and then
came Alec Randall, who had for his
subject "1918 at Homewood."
Then followed the two hits of
the, evening. Everett Sanner gave
"Casey at the Bat" in realistic form,
acting everything as he said it:
Reuben Oppenheimer then recited
two original poems, parodies on
"Danny Deever" and "Gonga Din."
Toastmaster Wolfe here called on
about a dozen of the members of
the class to tell of their experiences
during the fresh-soph struggle of.
that day or to tell of some college
activity in which they were espeThe banquet
cially interested.
closed with cheers for the class, its
members, and for the team.
The banquet committee consisted
of Henry Evans, chairman; Stuart
Egerton, Frank Sutton, Robert
Duncan and Robert Hoffman.
PRINCETON STATISTICS FURNISH
INTERESTING INFORMATION

The publication of the Princeton senior statistics has aroused
great discussion in college circles
throughout the country, both because of the actual information
conveyed, and because of the unusual nature of the canvass.
These statistics show that out of
230 men I9 are supporting themse:ves wholly and 38 partially.
Seven men have been suspended
from college. The average age of
the class is 21.7 years, one man
being only 18 years old.
Of the class 43 men declare that
they have . never kissed a girl.

CARROLL MANSION FOR CLUB

BALDWIN ASKS REPARATION

DO YOUR PRIMPING AT

Hopkins Club to Occupy Old Building
at Homewood Next Fall -Heating
and Lighting to Be
Altered.

Former Hopkins Professor Sends Stirring Cable to President, on Behalf
of His Injured Daughter Latter's Condition Critical.

The Citizens' Barber Shop

It has been definitely decided that
the Hopkins Club will occupy the
old Carroll Mansion when the University moves to Homewood next
fall. As the building is in need of
repairs, a committee consisting of
Messrs. Cator, Keyser and Radcliffe has been appointed to make
improvements. The committee, in
whose hands the entire matter has
been left, has had several architects
to look over the state of affairs and
to give estimates of the cost of the
needed renovations. As funds are
not plentiful, the treasurer has objected to a large appropriation.
However, $2,000 have been set
aside thus far.
The mansion must be altered
somewhat to suit the tastes and
needs of the club and yet its style
and colonial archecticture, both inside and out, must be kept intact.
No changes which will spoil the
design or alter in any way the appearance will be made. Of course,
this does not include papering and
painting; it is for these that the
estimates are being gathered.
Since gas is at present the only
means of illumination, an appropriation has been made to install
electric fixtures. Concerning the
heating apparatus no definite plans
have been decided upon. If the
heat could be secured from the
main supply-house of the University, it could be gotten more cheaply by the club and would aid the
University. This idea would necessitate the tearing up of the lawn
and campus to lay down the big
pipes. The house is now heated by
three large, but old fashioned furnaces, the upkeep of which is enormous compared with the cost of
heat from the main pipes.

Dr. James Mark Baldwin, a former Hopkins professor, who is a
survivor of the channel-ship Sussex
which sank recently as the result of
an explosion supposed to have been
caused by a German submarine attack, sent a cablegram last week to
President Wilson asking reparation
for the injuries received by his
daughter.
The cablegram read as follows:
"A woman traveling where her
right was, carrying an American
passport, stricken on the Sussex,
hovering between life and death,
demands that reparation for assault on American life and liberty
be exacted. MARK BALDWIN."
Miss Baldwin's injuries included
paralysis of the right side and she
was unable to speak from the time
of the accident until April 1, when
she recovered her voice. Her condition is still alarming serious and
it is supposed that Dr. Baldwin will
remain in Paris with his daughter
for some time to come.

by a court about 150 feet wide, the
